content: The curr_chunk is a section header titled "SHORT TITLE." The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes $103,000,000 for the Patent and Trademark Office for salaries and expenses in fiscal year 1994. This funding is derived from the Patent and Trademark Office Fee Surcharge Fund. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 established a fund under section 10101. Fees collected under title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946 are authorized to be made available to the Patent and Trademark Office for fiscal year 1994. SEC. 3. Amounts appropriated under this Act may remain available until expended. SEC. 4. The fee for filing a trademark registration application shall be $245, effective upon enactment, with adjustments not before October 1, 1994. SEC. 5. Interim patent extensions. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for extending the regulatory review period for patents under certain circumstances. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, allows for extending the regulatory review period for patents if the owner expects it to go beyond the patent expiration. The owner can apply for an interim extension 6 months before the term expires, providing details of the product under review and the relevant federal statute. The application for an interim extension under Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, must include details of the product under regulatory review, the relevant federal statute, the patent for which extension is sought, and activities undertaken for eligibility determination. The application for an interim extension under Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, must include details of the product under regulatory review, relevant federal statute, patent for which extension is sought, activities undertaken for eligibility determination, manufacturing information, brief description of applicant's activities during regulatory review period, significant dates, and any additional patent information required by the Commissioner. If the Commissioner determines that the patent would be eligible for an extension, except for permission to market or use the product commercially, the extension may be granted. The Commissioner may grant an interim extension for a patent if it would be eligible for extension under Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, except for commercial use. The extension can be for up to 1 year, and the owner of the patent can apply for up to 4 subsequent interim extensions. The owner of record of a patent can apply for up to 4 subsequent interim extensions, each lasting not more than 1 year. Each application must be made 60 to 30 days before the expiration of the preceding interim extension. Each certificate of interim extension shall be recorded in the official file of the patent. Each certificate of interim extension under this paragraph shall be recorded in the official file of the patent and considered part of the original patent. Any interim extension granted shall terminate 60 days after the product receives permission for commercial marketing or use, unless the applicant notifies the Commissioner and submits additional information within that period. The product involved can receive permission for commercial marketing or use, and the patent can be further extended for up to 5 years from the original patent term expiration date or from the date the product receives approval for commercial marketing or use. During the interim extension period, rights from an extended patent are limited to the specific use or method of using a product that is under regulatory review. During the interim extension period, rights from an extended patent are limited to the specific use or method of using a product that is under regulatory review. The extension specifies limitations for patents claiming products, methods of using products, and methods of manufacturing products under regulatory review. SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to clarify and update various subsections regarding rights and provisions. SEC. 7. PATENT TERM EXTENSIONS FOR AMERICAN LEGION. The design patents for the badges of the American Legion, American Legion Women's Auxiliary, and Sons of the American Legion are renewed and extended for 14 years from the date of enactment of the Act, with all associated rights and privileges. The design patents for the badges of the American Legion, American Legion Women's Auxiliary, and Sons of the American Legion are renewed and extended for 14 years from the date of enactment of the Act, with all associated rights and privileges. SEC. 8. INTERVENING RIGHTS. The renewals and extensions of patents under section 6 will not result in infringement for any use of the patent's subject matter that began after the patent expired but before the enactment of this Act.
